T-minus One Day.If we look back on 2015; it's easily going to be the year of spy movies. I mean; Mission Impossible, Kingsman, Bond and other smaller original flicks like The Man From U.N.C.L.E, or in this case; Spy. Yes it's a comedy, but does that make the film forced to be funny? Some of the humorous moments are flat and doesn't come as great as they could have come. But I still had a good time with its unpredictable storyline and random & hilarious jokes. But some moments are just slow and non-interesting and the movie lacks heart, especially when it comes to remembreble humorous scenes. Sure there are some of them but there aren't that many. The greatest aspect is on the other hand the well chosen actors and it's the personalities of the main characters that totally steals the show! The comedy-genre is a risky business; jokes will always grow old and Spy is no exception. It's an okay movie for the first-timer, but not more than that. I saw Spy yesterday, and yes I had a great time with it but I've already forgotten it, it's just a one-timer.But it's really enjoyable to watch, even though it lacks heart of a Mission Impossible-alike and less messier spy flick.6.5/10

Unoriginal, flatly executed, and overblown, Spy is the sort of comedy that thinks it's hilarious and assumes you do as well, without earning it. The very set-up of a heavy-set and mild mannered Melissa McCarthy being put in a James-bond esque role sounds perhaps mildly amusing, and it is, but its novelty wears off quickly. The gags are heavily exaggerated and much too drawn out, the plot absurdly nonsensical, and the humor much too one-note. The movie thinks constant fat/ugly jokes about McCarthy is simply hysterical, and thinks it's even more hysterical when she turns the tables by having an "f bomb" tirade. It's not. The film feels like an SNL skit stretched way too far.Disappointing.1.5/5 Stars

Summer's here, it's hot as hell, what is there to do? In America, we know the answer to that. Go to the movies. If you go anytime this week or next Spy will be one of the many summer flicks jockeying for your attention, (along with the much louder and CGI heavier Jurassic Park IV which just hit theaters today) but is it worth your ten bucks? I think it might be. If you think you'll be satisfied with no more than a few laughs and very few infuriating "comedy" movie moments (no needless dick punches, out of touch racists jokes, or babies puking on people in this movie).If you've seen the trailers then you know that this is a spy spoof. It's more in the vein of Kingsman than Austin Powers, though it is no way as good as either of those films. There are times when Spy goes too far with its mocking of its lead, Melissa McCarthy, but it isn't to the extreme as other movies she's starred in. No one points out her weight, it's more of about her being an outcast, almost "just because," though the unspoken understanding of these jokes is because she's overweight. These jokes don't come off funny, they feel over worn more than anything, and unfortunately they happen a lot in the first 30 minutes or so of the movie. After we get past that point though, it does pick up. Once Melissa's character goes rogue and starts spying it up (a.k.a beating the shit out of people in well choreographed fights scenes) it is actually pretty fun. It's also a relief to see Melissa hanging up her Chris Farley persona for this movie. She plays a regular person, not someone who takes pleasure in reminding the audience how loudly she can fart, which is a nice treat, because she is a fine actor, but like so many others she's found a niche that works, and she's been driving that persona home.Speaking of personas, Jason Statham plays an exaggerated version of his action star persona. He pops in the film every so often to throw a few more fucks into the dialogue along with some pretty funny jokes about the extremes he's gone in the past to prove just how much of a bad ass he is (pouring shards of broken glass into his eye, driving a car onto a moving train while he was on fire, ext.).As much as Spy would like to believe it's a genre mashup that transcends the goofy comedy genre, it really isn't. It's essentially just another run of the mill goofy comedy, but this one is trying harder, and does have some charm. Check it out if you're Avengered out, Jurassiced out, as well as Maxed out.
Spy offers further proof that Melissa McCarthy and writer-director Paul Feig bring out the best in one another and this is both their best.

Today i will be writing my review for the Paul Feig directed movie Spy starring Melissa McCarthy and Jason Statham.The film started out brilliantly and set a good tone for which I had hoped would last throughout the entire film. Jude law was an absolute bad ass early on, reminiscent of the Dr Watson roll he played in Sherlock Holmes, which totally had me thinking i was in for an amazing action movie.Oddly enough, Statham was mostly used for comedy relief, which is strange because almost every movie he is in (with the exception of snatch) he is usually wrecking shit and kicking ass, but they ended up making him an overly pissed off version of Mr. Bean.Melissa McCarthy basically plays the same "character" that she usually plays. You can expect a lot of "come on's" and a bevy of classic Mike and Molly anecdotes we have become WAY to accustomed to. That's not to say that she didn't have a couple of funny moments, but its more in the vein of like when you go and see a band like U2 live and they just put out a shitty album on your iPhone (which nobody asked for by the way) and you wish they would just play the classics from Joshua Tree but instead you get a whole concert of Songs of Innocence with Where the streets have no name and Bullet the Blue Sky peppered in to the act so the true fans don't completely revolt.Paul Feig once again surprised me with his amazing directing skills. The action scenes were fucking amazing and the way he shoots comedy has me a little more excited to see how he pulls of Ghostbusters.I was skeptical going into this movie especially after seeing The Heat (which i wish i could of unseen) but with a little optimism seeing how Feig also directed Bridesmaids which is the funniest comedy with an all female cast that i have ever seen.As decent as this movie was, it seems like the handjob (test) the girl your dating (the studio) gives you to check out your package (directing skills) before she decides if your big enough (money at the box-office) for her to want to allow you inside of her "box" (Big Name Movie Franchise).While the studio felt confident enough to give Feig a franchise as big as Ghostbusters, (which is the equivalent of getting access to the back door in terms of iconic comedies) i feel this movie was at least worth a blow job at best( a B list action comedy reboot with a famous enough name like Get Smart or Naked Gun).While this movie wasn't the best, it surely wasn't the worst movie i have seen this year, and while i don't heavily endorse it, its still good enough for a Redbox rental or a purchase on VOD (video on demand)

Spy is a really fresh comedy with Melissa McCarthy and Jude Law. The opening scene features Jude Law pointing a gun at the one man who knows the location of a nuclear weapon. He sneezes, accidently pulls the trigger, and kills the man. This is one of the funniest and most ridiculous opening scenes I've seen in awhile. Melissa McCarthy is usually over the top and annoying in most of her movies. They really force the lines and the comedy with her. She's a brilliant actress. I think she's just been subject to a lot of strange scripts and directing. She is absolutely hilarious in Spy. She's not over the top. She isn't annoying. She's clever and goofy and that girl can work a black dress. Her characters been stuck behind a desk assisting Jude Law on missions for her entire career. She's finally given the opportunity to get into the field and help locate a dangerous nuclear weapon. She's an amazing spy that hasn't been able to use her talents over the years. I laughed the entire time. It felt fresh and witty. The action was great. The entire movie was enjoyable and made me want to watch it again.

I waited until there was literally nothing else that I hadn't seen to go see this one and even then, it was just to pass a couple of hours between errands. Turns out it wasn't at all what I expected. It started out like a James Bond film with the music and action in the opening. So I figured I would at least stay awake.As the movie progressed and Melissa McCarthy's 'mousy' character became more involved, I began to perk up. The action increased and so did McCarthy's skill as first time field agent. She played a semi-serious and accidentally comic Jane Bond with a filthy mouth. I actually laughed out loud a few times (which I rarely do, even in a comedy) but was continually enthralled by the action sequences. It was also very funny to watch Jason Statham, the usually flawless main character, play a bumbling, agent out of control.Thanks to McCarthy, the language is out of control and I wouldn't recommend it for younger viewers but truthfully, that is what made her character so funny. Paul Feig's third (and certainly not last) collaboration with Melissa McCarthy is their best yet with a perfect blend of spoof and a surprisingly decent spy plot that never pushes the jokes too far and is also pretty kick-ass at times. Melissa McCarthy is nowhere near my favourite actress and some of her ad-libbing is torture to me, but she shocked me in this film with her physicality and ability to totally kick ass and hold her own with some great mean-spirited humour. The supporting cast is EXCELLENT with Jude Law playing the James Bond-type, Allison Janney playing the bitter commander, Rose Byrne playing the UBER BITCH villain, and Jason Statham completely stealing the show as an over-the-top agent with anger and ego issues that never stopped making me laugh. Rose Byrne, also a Feig collaborator killed it as the seductress villain and her snobby attitude led to some of the funniest dialogue in the movie and an exchange between her and McCarthy was so harsh I was almost in tears! As said before, while it parodies the spy genre, by the third act it is knee-deep in a perfectly functional spy plot which was impressive to see. It is definitely not for the faint-hearted as there is a fair bit of R-rated violence and pretty much non-stop swearing (mostly from Statham) but it's all in good fun. Greatest comedy of all time? Definitely not, but McCarthy proved here that she's more than a one-trick pony who is more than capable of doing both action and absurd comedy.

Melissa McCarthy is a comedy giant; there is no denying that. She exploded first with a supporting role in Bridesmaids, which earned her an Oscar nomination. She went on to champion in TV as well, earning an Emmy for her role in Mike & Molly. She's also been a box-office assurance with Bridesmaids and The Heat each generating more than $150 million. So there is no denying that McCarthy is funny. A great amount of her hilarity comes from improvised scenes where one finds her spurting out rapid insults and one-liners that have the audience rolling on the ground laughing. Her newest comedy film: Spy only confirms her stance as the go to comedy actor of today.  Spy (surprisingly no movie before in history has had this title) tells the story of a CIA operative, Susan Cooper (Melissa McCarthy) who helps field agents navigate when on a mission, she is the "voice in the ear" for her assigned agent: Bradley Fine (Jude Law) whom she also happens to have a crush on. However, after the covers of all field CIA agents are blown, CIA chief Elaine Crocker (Allison Janney) is forced to send a fresh face into the field, thus Cooper is sent to Paris. In Paris, Cooper must track the oily-haired Mafioso Sergio De Luca (Bobby Cannavale) in order to figure out the location of a missing nuke. The majority of the film is planned to generate laughs from physical comedy, but thankfully the arguments between McCarthy and Jason Stantham, who plays hardcore rogue agent, fill in gaps between the action scenes in an equally entertaining way. In the end however the big supporting cast (which also includes Rose Byrne as the main villainess) seems to not be fully taken advantage of. McCarthy holds her own, but the screen does end up hogging her. The film could have used more Jason Stantham and a surprising Miranda Hart who plays Cooper's best friend at the CIA. Director Paul Feig (who previously worked with McCarthy on Bridesmaids and The Heat) does a good job at distracting the audience, so much that we forget how clich�d the film is with spy and 007 jokes. Even halfway through the film the audience doesn't notice that the story has been going nowhere for over an hour. I think that that is an incredible achievement: to have the audience so entertained they don't focus on the little details and cracks in an artist's work. In the end the move is a good laugh. Some jokes fall flat, but the majority makes it through to your smile thanks to an amazing supporting cast and a more than capable star.

"Spy" is a comedic-female version of James Bond with a lot more hilarious trash-talk and more failed missions than one would expect from a so-called "Spy" movie.Melissa McCarthy plays Susan Cooper, a stereotypical shy genius who works in a secret CIA underground facility. She is the right-hand man to Bradley Fine, portrayed by pretty boy actor Jude Law. Cooper's role was to help support Fine from behind the scenes by assisting him via Bluetooth in which she lets him know where enemies are approaching, how many people are surrounding him, and ordering missiles to shoot at precise locations she provides when the time calls for it. Cooper had a one-sided love with Fine and when she thought Fine had died at the hands of an arms dealer, she began the plan to avenge his death. The aforementioned arms dealer goes by the name of Raina. She is played by the devilishly beautiful Rose Byrne. Right after Raina supposedly killed Fine, she revealed that she knows all the true identities of the CIA agents in the field. This, along with her plot to avenge the man she loves' death, caused Cooper to volunteer to go out into the field to find Raina and track down a stolen nuclear bomb. "Spy" isn't only about capturing the bad guys. This movie shows the evolution of a woman who was invisible to both her peers and the man that she loved, to becoming a spy who kicks butt in the field and saves the day. Cooper was unknown to the villains of this movie because she kept her head down in the CIA and operated in the background. Now, she calls her own shots and leads others into battle. She developed confidence in her line of work and has a newfound sense of respect for herself by loving who she is and not being ashamed of it. The only questionable part about this movie was the director's casting choice of Bradley Fine. Jude Law certainly had the looks for the part, but Ryan Gosling would have made a better Fine. Gosling would have put more of a charm towards Fine's personality, which would have made more sense seeing as how Cooper fell for him. Gosling would have made a more convincing character as Fine and would have overall made the movie blend better together. Throughout the movie is a series of endless laughs and witty comebacks. This movie is a mix between James Bond and Paul Blart: Mall Cop. Although this movie shows these spies having some amazing skills in kicking the bad guy's butts, this movie also shows idiotic failings a 10 year old could figure out (like not storming into a black market bomb deal and knocking yourself out, Ford). If you want to see a successful and witty hero in an action packed movie, then go watch TNT movies on the television. However, if you want a good laugh see things get blown up, then this is the movie for you.

Melissa McCarthy has been America's finest comedienne ever since she knocked us all out with her all-hands-on-deck supporting performance in 2011's "Bridesmaids". Not a Lucy nor a Rosalind, McCarthy has always gone down and dirty, packing her yearly schedule with comedy parts built around her foul mouthed persona. But after a few too many misses, such as inexplicably high-grossing "Identity Thief" or critical disaster "Tammy", one has begun to associate McCarthy with a wig and a greasy part, embodying a character better equipped for a Saturday Night Live skit than a full length movie.  Finally, we have a vehicle worthy of her talents: "Spy" is the best comedy of the year. One shouldn't be saying such things until December, I know, but I doubt I'll find another romp as packed with belly laughs as this one. I haven't laughed this hard, or this uninterruptedly, for months. And I'm not being overly dramatic - with increasing embarrassment, I found tears streaming down my face quite often, doing everything possible to quiet down potentially obnoxious laughing fits. It's been a month since the film was released - the theater was hardly packed - but it was clear that the people around me were in similar states of shock. This is a comedy worth celebrating. As soon as I left the theater, I wanted to see it again. (Pardon the clich�: there's a reason we have them.) In "Spy", McCarthy portrays Susan Cooper, a CIA analyst who spends her days acting as the well-trained ear to 007-esque field agent Bradley Fine (Jude Law). She's been stuck at her desk for years, aiding him on each and every mission - it's only inevitable that she, a lonely heart who hasn't been in a relationship for a while - fall for his charming ways. But after an incident leaves him out of the picture, Susan realizes that she would make for a good spy: she is knowledgeable when it comes to the field and knows quite a bit of self defense. Reluctantly, her supervisor (Alison Janney) agrees with her suggestion, sending her to Paris to thwart a terrorism plot involving powerful criminals Sergio De Luca (Bobby Cannavale) and Rayna Boyanov (Rose Byrne). Constantly interrupting the mission is Rick Ford (Jason Statham), a rogue agent who lets his ego get in the way of successful plotting. Though initially nervous, Susan finds herself thrilled by her new job - she might even be, dare she say it, better than Fine.  Paul Feig, the man behind "Bridesmaids" and "The Heat", mixes action and comedy with such skill that we almost forget that seeing McCarthy convincingly fist fight with a baddie should seem strange - but McCarthy, thanks to a terrific comedic performance and Feig's screenplay, is never anything less than a wrecking ball of laughs. She can sell a barbed insult as well as she can make the most of her initially mousy fa�ade - McCarthy is one of the greatest comedy actors of the 2010s. It's easy to forget that fact when she heads bombs, but when films like "Spy" come along, we begin to realize just how wrong we were to ever underestimate her.  For once, though, McCarthy is not the only actor providing the majority of our abdominal pain. The responsibility is shared by a fantastic, sometimes surprisingly so, ensemble: Byrne, an under-appreciated straight woman, murders her role as the big-haired villainous; Miranda Hart, as McCarthy's ear, is a fine combination of bumbling and shrill; Janney's no-nonsense portrayal provides for some of the most hard-hitting laughs in the film. But best is, shockingly, Statham, who lampoons his image so hilariously one can only wonder what's been keeping him out of the comedy world all these years. I loved "Spy". I don't go to the theaters often - money, you see, is too sacred to constantly spend on entertainment - but I haven't had this much fun in the cinema chair for what feels like years. Sometimes, it's good to laugh until you cry; sometimes, it's good to want to turn around and see the movie all over again. Netflix is cheaper, I know, but don't wait to see "Spy". Go out on the town with your friends, ending your night with it. I guarantee you'll still be laughing for the next few days.

The large cast of Spy works impressively from Melissa's witty, fumbling "Susan Cooper", Jude Law's egotistical "Bradley Fine", Rose Byrne's uptight villainous "Rayna", and Jason Statham's hilarious, over the top "Rick Ford".Spy's genre is action, comedy and it does both brilliantly. The action set pieces are put together with style and many of the more intense, up close action sequences feel extremely fluid. The knife fight were "Coop" tries to fend off an enemy by use of various kitchen equipment is funny and very impressive to watch.The comedic aspect of this film is also perfectly captured through character dialogue and visual gags, the cast chemistry also adds to some truly laugh out loud moments.Statham's "Rick Ford" proved one of my favorite characters. His crazy tales are used to improve upon his super spy status and are gut wrenching throughout as he always seems to pop up to ruin Susan's plans. As for negatives with Spy other than Rose Byrne's character "Rayna" the villains are very one note and quite forgettable. Also the plot gets a little too convoluted towards the end and the few twists are extremely clich�.Overall I had a very enjoyable time watching Spy and at times it had me bursting out with laughter.

This film motivated me to create an account on Rotten Tomatoes and write a review. I can't remember the last time I disliked a movie as much as this one.Framed in the style of Bond flicks, but thrown off the deep end with slapstick, this movie reeks of repetitiveness and ridiculous unrealism. This is the kind of comedy McCarthy usually excels at, but with Feig trying to replicate the dynamic presence McCarthy had on "The Heat", this comedy falls short in every way.McCarthy is brilliant in this film, but she simply isn't able to carry the whole movie on her back. Stratham adds some spontaneity to the mix with his brash and brazen, over the top character who seems to have a fish story for everything, but his role seems a bit second fiddle, and he's not able to contribute as much as he should. I would have liked to have seen him and McCarthy in a more amicable partnership rather than the jaded spy being an idiot while the no-experience analyst/sort-of spy saves his ass all the time.This movie didn't rise to the level of a spoof, and so people are left to categorize it in the action-comedy genre, and it just doesn't cut the cake. Don't get me wrong, the bathroom humor and bats flying out of the ceiling are funny in a Jim Carrey sort of way, but if you're over eleven it gets old fast.

I'm definitely in the minority of people who did not really like "Bridesmaids" all that much. Perhaps by the time I saw it, the movie had gotten so much praise that there was no way it was going to live up to the expectation that I had set for it to achieve. It's not like I went into it with a negative attitude like "I've heard lots of good things so you better not disappoint me," but rather an excited attitude of "everyone says this movie is amazing, I can't believe I'm finally going to get to see it!" The reason I didn't like it is probably a combination of unrealistic expectations and simply not finding it to be all that funny. I never ended up seeing "The Heat" but I had heard good things. When my roommate excitedly suggested we see "Spy," I was well aware it had a 98% on Rotten Tomatoes but for some reason I just wasn't interested and actually fought against us going to see it. I was in for a surprise when I begrudgingly tagged along and found myself laughing far more often and much harder than my roommate who suggested we see it in the first place. It's interesting that Melissa McCarthy has blown up so much since "Bridesmaids" but just about every movie she's headlined since then, that isn't Paul Feig-directed, has been a huge critical disaster. There have been box office hits but nothing well received from critics. For some reason, Feig has the great ability to write and direct McCarthy better than anyone else (better than her own husband did in last year's "Tammy"). He is somehow uniquely able to channel her specific energy into performances that remind us why she is a modern comedy staple (that and the fact that she always has solid stints hosting SNL). While I am not sure what to make of this, it probably just means that Feig is a more adept writer-director than his contemporaries that have directed McCarthy. "Spy" takes a while to pick up some steam. Going in, I was not excited at the idea of Jude Law being funny. I'm fine with serious actors taking a stab at comedy but something about Law always just strikes me as bland. So the first bit of the movie was only reaffirming my want to not be in the theater. It is not until Jason Statham appears on screen that I really started to laugh, and boy did I start. He steals just about every scene he enters and one of my biggest complaints about the film is that he isn't in it enough. Some might argue that's a good thing, it's better to leave the audience wanting more rather than leave them feeling like they got way too much. While this is normally true, I genuinely believe the movie would have greatly benefitted by giving him a few more standout moments. About halfway through the movie, McCarthy's character hits a turning point and we get to see that aggressive side of her that (under Feig's direction) leaves you rolling with laughter in your seat. She riffs off line after line of great, gruesome and off-the-wall insults to the characters surrounding her. Rose Byrne reaffirms that she is a comedy force to be reckoned with after her turns in "Get Him to the Greek," Bridesmaids" and "Neighbors." She effectively plays the villain but there is a clever plot device that allows her to spend some buddy-buddy time with McCarthy and they play off each other so well. "Spy" is a little too long and it wears on you by the end. There is also a cameo from 50 Cent that didn't really play that well with me or my theater and perhaps that is mostly due to his somewhat recent decline in cultural relevance. I can't help but think his cameo would have been a huge deal in 2005, but realistically, he wouldn't have wanted to do a comedy cameo at the height of his career in 2005 anyway. The movie is far from perfect but it has plenty of laughs to justify seeing it in theaters.
A likeable cast and a couple of very, very funny moments....but that's it. Reminds me a lot of Bridesmaids. Perfectly pleasant, but horrifically overrated.

Spy is essentially a Melissa McCarthy action-comedy vehicle. Among her comedic peers, McCarthy is currently the reigning box-office draw. And it isn't hard to see why as she infuses the film with impressive physical and obvious verbal comedy. The most attractive part of Spy for audiences is the cast: McCarthy is clearly the star, but her supporting cast is strong as well. (1) Rose Byrne plays the Bulgarian villainess; Byrne is currently doing many comedic/silly films in order to soften her image (which is a result from the Damages TV Series) and she seems to be achieving success. (2) Jason Statham plays an over-the-top rogue who is as intense as he is clueless; it is a nice change of pace for the action film vet. (3) Finally, long-time character actress Allison Janney virtually steals the show from her co-stars as the wise-cracking CIA boss. Due to the strong script from writer-director Paul Feig, Spy is a character-driven comedy first and a plot driven comedy second. In other words, the comedy comes before the action and the result is lots of laughs.

SpyIn theatresRating: R 120 minutes Action/Comedy3 1/2 starsDirector: Paul FeigWriter: Paul FeigStarring: Melissa McCarthy, Rose Byrne and Jude LawSusan Cooper (McCarthy) is an "agent" (who is viewed as a secretary because she isn't in the field) of the CIA. She is agent Bradley Fine's (Law's) eyes and ears. Think James Bond - and she has a wild crush on him. He doesn't know it.An atomic bomb has been stolen and Fine is sent to retrieve it. But, it's a set up and Fine is killed - as Cooper watches helpless from the main office. Their boss (Allison Janney) knows that the top agents' identities have all been compromised. She needs an unknown. Cooper asks for the assignment - Ford (Jason Statham), a hot-headed agent refuses to hide, and goes rogue, seeking revenge.Cooper ends up with the assignment "to watch and track" only. Ford hinders her movements while Cooper tries to find the woman who killed Fine. What she gets mixed up seems over her head: spies, double agents, and weapon sellers (bitchy and witchy played by Rose Byrne).Brilliant comedy. We continued laughing long after the joke was told. This is a must see.Fieg is well known in Hollywood. From television (acting, producing and writing, including The Office {Emmy nomination and DGA Award} and Freaks and Geeks), film (producing, directing and writing notably Bridesmaids.)Producer John J. Kelly has 54 credits to his name: Into the Wild, 127 Hours, Divergent, The Black Dahlia and on and on.

Entertaining, enjoyable and highly unpredictable, "Spy" is a rare comedy that offers consistent laughs from start to finish. Although the plot may seem familiar on paper, it is filled with enough twists and turns that keep the audience at the edge of their seat. When it comes to acting, each and every star is perfectly cast in their role. Melissa McCarthy, Jason Statham and Rose Byrne are all hilarious to watch, simply irreplaceable in their roles. Statham, in particular, proves to have a gift and knack for comedy. An actor mostly known for action blockbusters, he reveals unique talents in this film that prove he's more than just an action-hero. McCarthy, on the other hand, carries the film with her sharp humor and perfect sense of comedic timing. Despite these unforgettable performances, however, the film is let down by nonsensical twists towards the second half. Also, some jokes fall flat mainly due to their 'disgust' factor. Nevertheless, this is a comedy that's worth watching alone for one of the funniest performances that Melissa McCarthy has ever given.

As sensible and logical (i.e. not very) as a Bond film during the Roger Moore years and equally funny (though more intentional than unintentional here), this is a winning and charming film that proves Melissa McCarthy can carry a comedy; although it must also be said that she is surrounded by a very competent and equally hilarious supporting cast. While Miranda Hart, playing a version of herself (no stretch there), doesn't make you wince watching her "act", it is more surprising to find Jason Statham and Rose Bryne being able to not only make fun of themselves but also to deliver comedic lines with great timing . But MVP here is writer-director, Paul Feig, who balances action with comedy with skills aplomb. The narrative is not exactly original or unpredictable but played straight as a Bond spoof, it dissects the genre and plays up its pomposity and ridiculousness with plenty of details and nuances that would impress any Bond or spy film aficionados. It certainly gives me great hopes that the female Ghostbusters reboot might stand a chance in succeeding in Feig and McCarthy's hands.

THE WOMAN WITH THE GOLDEN CHARM - My Review of SPY (3 1/2 Stars)Paul Feig and Melissa McCarthy are kind of having a moment right now. Perfectly matched as director/writer and actor respectively, this Dream Team delivered big laughs in both BRIDESMAIDS and THE HEAT. With SPY, the don't disappoint, in fact, they've added some terrific filmmaking to their repertoire. SPY plays like a Bond film, but with McCarthy's brand of outrageous, fearless and funny underdog added to the recipe. What I love about all three films are those extended diversions from the main story, where characters get stuck on a minor detail, effectively stopping the plot for a few delicious moments. It's something Mel Brooks and Gene Wilder excelled at in the 70s and it's in almost every scene in SPY. The opening sequence is a killer, with McCarthy's Agent Susan Cooper talking into Bond substitute Bradley Fine's ear. He's played by a very game Jude Law, who clearly enjoys towing the line between suave and douchey, sometimes within a single line of dialogue. I could have watched McCarthy be his office bound eyes and ears for the entire film, but there's that pesky thing called a story to tell. After a crazy inciting incident, the plot mechanics dictate that poor, put-upon Susan needs to get out into the field to help solve a crime. With her assistant Nancy in place, played by the extremely entertaining Miranda Hart, Susan receives a dumpy undercover assignment from her tough-as-nails boss, the always reliable Allison Janney. After a very funny gadget scene in which Susan and Nancy geek out hilariously over the oddly disappointing tools at their disposal, off we jet to Paris. It's the dark, seedy underbelly of Paris, so don't expect glamour. Besides, McCarthy settling into her "crime scene" hotel room is better than a tour of the Louvre. Feig's script does a wonderful job setting up Susan's character, with McCarthy bringing just the right amount of pathos and confidence to the material. It's so easy to fall in love with her, because she clearly has great detective skills and refuses to let anybody box her into a corner. At some point, a spy thriller needs its super-villain, and Rose Byrne fills those 6-inch stilettos perfectly as Rayna Boyanov, a condescending, rude, big-haired monster. Byrne has become a bit of a comedy secret weapon after years of honing her dramatic skills, and here she steals every scene she's in, sometimes with just a sneer. Watch for her response to a toast, and you'll feel you've gotten your money's worth from that moment alone. With BRIDESMAIDS, THE NEIGHBORS and now this film, Byrne has proven she can take a stock role and turn it into gold. Also along for the ride is a surprisingly funny Jason Statham as a shadow agent who continuously insinuates himself into McCarthy's investigation. His lines aren't the funniest, and truth be told, it becomes a little one note, but I enjoyed how much he threw himself into it, especially the end credits tag. Sure, SPY brings the laughs, although I could have done without 50 Cent's awkward, unfunny extended cameo, but the surprise here is the thrill of the action sequences. Feig directs these with such muscle and gusto, I wanted to applaud. Whether it's a chase scene through the streets or an epic kitchen fight using knives and pots and pans, Feig understands kinetics and momentum, which is rare in a comedy director. It's exciting to see a writer/director with one type of talent stretch and excel at another. Underneath this 007 splendor is a message of female empowerment and bonding, something usually lacking in Bond's universe. SPY takes back the night and makes you root for women in a way that feels exhilarating. That's no small feat for a dopey comedy.

Melissa McCarthy's meteoric comedic rise hasn't been without its missteps, mainly the complaint that she seems stuck in a rut playing aggressively weird and foul-mouthed characters that are growing tiresome. McCarthy is never better than when teamed with her Bridesmaids' director Paul Feig, and Spy is a welcomed return to form for a great comic actress who relishes being outlandish. The best part of the film is that it's a character-centric comedy, with McCarthy as Susan Cooper, a CIA agent who works as a handler, the voice on the other end of the earpiece, guiding her partner the handsome Agent Bradley Fine (Jude Law). When Fine is compromised on a mission, Susan unexpectedly finds herself in the field to track down some very bad people. McCarthy does get to be vulgar, but fortunately it's only one persona she adopts as a mask, and it's cleverly utilized. Feig's screenplay makes sure to find different comic beats as it goes, rarely repeating itself and, like any good action movie, finding twists to further develop conflicts. Part of what's so enjoyable about Spy is how comic scenarios will evolve while staying true to the characters and the central conflict. Also, Feig acquits himself more than well with the film's semi-slick action photography. The supporting cast is nicely tied into the story and matter and each actor has material to cut loose, none more than Jason Statham (The Expendables) as a hilariously boastful and incredulous agent. His boisterous chest-beating about his past deeds are some of the film's funniest moments. Consistently funny, witty, and mildly progressive with its heroine, Spy is a vehicle that makes perfect use of McCarthy's talents and then some. Nate's Grade: B+

Movie SpyI don't believe that it would be a spoiler alert if I said the violence was gratuitous, graphic, and realistic. The fights were like watching replays of sports injury plays, in close up slow motion. . All the violence in the movie added much entertainment value to those who find bone crushing entertaining or the entry of bullets and knifes into the human body educational, strictly from a medical standpoint of course. Three stooges fans will recognize and maybe enjoy the many stooges routines used in the fight scenes. The only difference is the fight scene was the last scene for many of the performers.I think it's ok if I reveal that the writers we're going for a record number of "F" bombs in the movie, and they succeeded. You might enjoy counting them to see if I'm right. you may find the volume of them unnecessary to the plot as I do, and counting them could add to the entertainment value of the movie.But the line in the movie that disturbed me the most, and this may be considered a spoiler alert, was a scene where the main character ask one of the villains of the movie if she was texting while they were talking. The response was: "no, I'm playing candy crush and I made it to level 75". This line didn't scared me because adults watching the movie understood the humor of the line but that they identified with the speaker of the line. It brought chills to my spine. Why "horror" wasn't added to the movie classification is beyond me.

Spy is an action comedy starring Melissa McCarthy and Jason Statham and it does a pretty damn good job at blending comedy with action. The action scenes were entertaining and accompanied with some subtle comedy as well as some over the top comedy it really made the last 3/4 of this film fun. The first 15-20 minutes wasn't that great, it was setting up characters and the main plot, and although it had a few laughs, it was quickly losing my interest. And there were one or two more times where it was showing signs of losing it but in comes Jason Statham to save the day because he was by far the highlight of this film. Who knew an action star would be the funniest aspect of a Melissa McCarthy led comedy film. I personally am not a giant fan of her but she has proved to be able to carry a film with her comedy before, so i was surprised when Statham completely stole the show time and time again. As for the plot it was a fun ride, there were times where it got a little silly but overall i was engaged in what was going and they did a good job. One issue with the plot is that similar to 'Focus' there were just too many twists, they were doing a good job at keeping me interested without the twists and the constant surprises got a little dumb but it's just a fairly minor flaw.The performances were, almost, all good and although the characters were a little cartoony the film was aware of that so it made it ok. Melissa McCarthy, Jason Statham, Rose Byrne, they all did a good job and were pretty funny but man, Miranda Hart's her character was just not good at all. Whenever she was in the film i wanted her out as soon as possible, and she kept on showing up making me sigh every time, her character was way too over the top and not funny at all, could have definitely done without her, in terms of comedy. In the end it has its fair share of action and comedy and an interesting plot after the first 15 minutes, so you can have a pretty fun time watching this film. - 7.6

Spy is a very entertaining and slightly original take on spies in a humorous way that isn't Austin Powers-y.Spy stars Melissa McCarthy, Jason Statham and Rose Byrne and is directed by Paul Feig, This movie stands out in more than just its comedy, but also its action and plot. The plot focuses on McCarthy's character Susan Cooper who is a CIA computer scientists that aids agents in the field from her desk. She is then called to action to track down an arms deal where Rose Byrne's character, Raina Boyanov, is selling a nuclear bomb to De Luca, a wealthy businessman. The great thing about this film is Melissa McCarthy, which is honestly a surprise since audiences have grown less and less fond of the same old character that McCarthy plays, but in this movie she shines as an accomplished comedian that really makes your stomach hurt from laughter. Her improv is absolutely fantastic in this movie when her character grows from being a timid desk worker to a much more confident and ruthless agent that really brings home the insults. Jason Statham also shines in the movie and really steals the scenes that he is in. His character, Rick Ford, is very much a spoof of the multiple badass characters that Statham plays in his other action movies. This is really really well done and Statham shows that even he can make fun of how outlandishly unrealistic some of his action movies are when Rick Ford goes on his long monologue about all the insane and dangerous things he has done in the field, such as reattaching a limb to his body. But the real star of this film is Paul Feig. Feig really presents his well-done action scenes really well, and this could even be seen as an audition tape for Feig to do action movies, because the guy can really do action well. His timing for shots for comedy are also spot on and with the help of McCarthy's wonderful improv lines, they are really able to work off each other in a very fun and entertaining way. The homages and winks to other spy films, namely James Bond, are also a great addition to this movie that makes the movie that much more of what it is, a spy movie.The only reason I tick off a star for this movie is that the plot points and storyline of this film are very much taken from other spy films. The timid computer analyst that is suddenly brought into the field is reminiscent of Get Smart, and the whole nuclear bomb mission scenario is very generic and almost uninteresting, but the way the movie presents the problem and the road to the end of the mission is very fun and interesting, and leaves room for a sequel which I am looking forward to.

Melissa McCarthy is very funny. Given room to work has been both freeing and constricting for her career. In last year's Tammy, she was given plenty of room to work, with her husband behind the camera, but the results were frustrating to say the least. In Spy, she reteams with Bridesmaids director Paul Feig. Feig utilizes McCarty to the best of his abilities, as a dowdy CIA desk jockey, Susan Cooper. McCarthy plays awkward and unsure with uncanny timing.  As the film moves along, active CIA agents are uncovered by a spoiled rich girl with a mean streak named Raina (A coldly hilarious Rose Byrne). This forces Cooper into the field, armed with a dart-gun rape whistle, kitty sweater and a cavalcade of old lady wigs. The banter between McCarthy and Byrne is both a great strength and weakness. Many of the insane tangents McCarthy goes on, as she gains confidence as an agent, and the return quips from Byrne seem improvised and many are hilarious. As we progress through the action, those tangents begin to wear on you, until the hilariously outrageous becomes ok, let's move on. The same can be said at first for the hilarious tangents of Agent Ford (Jason Statham skewering his tough guy persona).  Spy picks up the slack with its physical humor. This is where McCarthy really excels. There are three great fight scenes/slapstick show cases that bring the belly laughs. Feig makes sure that the action, while hilarious, is still technically impressive. The plot is pretty standard action movie fare. The heroes are in pursuit of villains, who have stolen a nuclear bomb. The streamlined plot, is just enough to keep the audience interested, while giving McCarthy plenty of room to flex her comedy muscles. Along the way, Susan Cooper bursts out of the box her peers and society put her in. This plot point runs parallel with the actress who plays her. In Spy, McCarthy frees herself from her supporting actress role to full-fledged star. She brings the laughs. Feig supplies the thrills. With Spy, this winning duo has churned out a continuously funny and exiting piece of summer entertainment.

I went to see this movie based almost entirely on the very positive reviews that riddle this website. The conclusion I reached as the credits mercifully rolled was that someone either in Melissa McCarthy's family or a group of Paul Feig's minions must have spent hours writing these reviews. This movie missed on almost every single level from beginning to end. The only genuine laugh it evoked was by a small and questionable cameo by rapper 50 Cent at the very end. The jokes were cliche and played out with the same, tired McCarthy "fat girl" spin that had everyone peeing their pants over Bridesmaids and somehow keeps her in starring roles. The overwhelming feeling that you had seen and heard everything from this movie before was too much to handle for most of this film and if it wasn't for Jason Statham acting as some much needed relief from McCarthy's whining I may have taken a prolonged trip to the bathroom. What caught my eye most of all was the complete over use of profanities by everybody in the cast. The only person that sounded remotely comfortable dropping strings of F-Bombs was Statham who really can be funny when he wants to be. Rose Byrne, McCarthy and Miranda Hart (who was DREADFUL) frequently utilized cringe-worthy tyrades of cursing in exchange for actual comedic dialogue. The bottom-line is the movie had potential to be funny in so many ways with a cast that had everyone in the theater ready to laugh and it fell flat on it's convoluted face. Not the face of the dashing Jude Law who was insignificant to not only the story but simply seemed disinterested in what was going on. I will now question very sincerely the reviews on this website as they are usually dependable. Something is either very wrong with the rating system or enough people are on the take because this movie shares very, very little redeeming qualities.  I don't even want my money back I think I just need to stay away from movie theaters for awhile.

Easily the best headlining outing for Melissa McCarthy to date, Spy is an enjoyable, diverting romp. Its true strength is that it manages to avoid the low-brow depths one could expect in such a venture and turns out to be quite clever and sharply written. McCarthy herself surprised me in with some great deadpan humor and aptly timed crass, ridiculous, and quotable dialogue. Jude Law and Rose Byrne succeed in their self-concerned "straight man" roles and Jason Statham largely plays a caricature of himself to great effect. Most of the set pieces work and the violence is satisfyingly gory. Spy is similar to another R-rated espionage spoof that came out in 2015 - Kingsman: The Secret Service. But as where Kingsman was a brilliant, dark, and cruel send up of Roger Moore-era Bond movies, Spy is more warm-hearted and cute, once you get past the F-bombs and bloody head shots. There are few, if any true villains. We are here to watch idiots fight and curse at one another, and then laugh about it later. I am sure there is some context about the protagonist defying the expectations of her gender, weight, and lack of attractiveness, but I honestly didn't care. The fact that this movie wasn't a trainwreck was quite impressive and the fact that it's actually pretty fun is a miracle.

Chris Rock flawlessly transitioned from years of stand-up television comedy to instant, overnight leading movie star in 2014's hilarious movie "Top Five". Could funny woman Melissa McCarthy make a similar move from television ("Gilmore Girls" and "Mike & Molly") to big screen headliner? We saw a glimpse of McCarthy's serious acting chops in last year's dramedy "St Vincent", a smashing movie performance opposite Bill Murray's eccentric character. Introduced to most of us in 2011's hilarious "Bridesmaids", the former high school cheerleader has since co-starred, but never held, the top billing in a comedy of her own. Until now. For "Spy", McCarthy carries this movie on her back using perfectly timed slapstick comedy and never taking herself or the film's lightweight plot too seriously. Teamed up once again with director Paul Feig ("Bridesmaids", "The Heat"), McCarthy returns to her comedy roots in this whimsical spoof on our Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine operations. As CIA analyst Susan Cooper, McCarthy ventures out into the undercover spook world in an attempt to thwart rogue arms dealers and protect her Langley associates. Nicely complimenting McCarthy's tongue-and-cheek humor is a tuxedoed Jude Law in a passable tribute to Her Majesty's 007. Fellow "Bridesmaids" cast member Rose Byrne ably rejoins McCarthy in "Spy" as the deadly daughter of a mob boss. But its former martial artist James Statham who easily earns the most laughs behind McCarthy once the final scorecard is tallied. Other crowd pleasers who bring smiles to viewers include former "West Wing" TV series' spokeswoman Allison Janney as the CIA's deputy director while Morena Baccarin, from Showtime's "Homeland" series (Mrs Jessica Brody), stars as a seductive CIA operative.Is "Spy" the funniest movie I've ever seen? No. Not by a longshot. But it does provide hysterical comparisons to the three stealthiest JB's in the undercover biz: James Bond, Jason Bourne and Jack Bauer. If you've enjoyed the Austin Powers' trilogy of spy parodies and can handle F-bombs tossed in every direction throughout, you'll find this film's physical comedy and witty presentation also agreeable. No one in Hollywood has a better comedic game right now than Melissa McCarthy. "Spy" works because McCarthy can deliver laughs with a simple look, deadpan line or uncomfortable run/walk. The "Bridesmaids" alumnus has effortlessly transformed herself from Emmy winning television comedian into a bona fide motion picture headliner. While her cousin Jenny McCarthy may get the most double-takes from magazine photos, it's this McCarthy that is sure-fire bet at the box office. Look for Melissa to continue her meteoric rise on the big screen well into 2016. Grade: B+

"Spy" is the funniest film I've seen in a long time. It does to spy films what "Shrek" did to fairy tales. It turns conventions upside down, yet retains an entertaining and funny story. It starts by taking us down the conventional spy genre from the start. The first few minutes could easily be a James Bond movie with Jude Law in the role, but soon we are taken on a different path. When Melissa McCarthy is thrust into the field, we get surprised and delighted as she ends up being effective despite (or perhaps because of) her non-conformity to role expectations. The rest of the cast is also fantastic. Rose Byrne is great with her constant put downs. Miranda Hart is also terrific, especially in the second half of the film I could not take my eyes off her and found that she stole scenes with great one liners or even just funny mannerisms. Jason Statham was also delivering great lines in a comically dead pan voice. The most plaudits must however go to Paul Feig for managing to create a film that was hilarious yet also riveting through its many plot twists and action sequences. His writing was so brilliantly specific to each character, something that only heightened the comedy. There were also many occasions during the film when lines became inaudible due to the laughter of myself and the audience at a previous line or action. This is the kind of comedy you can watch over and over again because you probably missed many jokes during the movie. It also manages even to argue feminism while being hilarious! The dialogues are sharp and smart and the comedic timing is quite perfect. There characters have real chemistry. It is a bit predictable at some point, but that doesn't harm the movie. It's a movie that really works.
Some misses by a small margin, but lots of great hits as well.

I wasn't expecting much, so I was happily surprised to find that this movie was HILARIOUS!! When we left the theater, everybody was talking about how much they loved it!

Though it's not as much as a hoot as I hoped it would be, the swell performances from a great cast and solid jokes make Spy an entertaining and funny enough mainstream comedy. The entire cast is solid and flawlessly picked. Each character has a distinct and loud personality that allows for fun interactions between characters. They make the film very entertaining, each distinct and a welcome sight whenever they come on screen. Melissa McCarthy carries the film very well, creating someone who is as easy to care for as she is to laugh at/with. If I were to pick characters who I found to be highlights it would be difficult not to mention everyone.Spy's funnies are usually clever and well-thought out, never resorting to dumb gags and typical jokes. This means that even when the jokes aren't hilarious they don't fall on their faces, and when they work they work nicely. Funny scenes to me where one where McCarthy and Law's characters are having dinner together, as well as a scene where McCarthy and Hart's characters are at a table just talking. These scenes feature smart, witty dialogue, with the actors enhancing it through character and sometimes complex expressions and tones.Another highlight for me was when Statham's character listed the badass things he's done as a professional. He's surprisingly funny in the role.Most of the funnies also happened to be in the first half, which seems to be a trend in many comedies. After a while, the film recycles the kind of jokes it's making, and they become familiar and less effective. For example, the amount of "You look like a ____" jokes, despite often being clever, is excessive. One small character in the film plays off of the same joke the entire time. McCarthy and Byrne's characters develop a chemistry that didn't totally make sense to me based purely on insults. Paul Feig seems to have a thing with insults. He's not bad at them, but there's so many that the humor is less dynamic. Feig's action directing is given slightly more care than you might expect from the comedy director, mostly in that the action is very coherent and doesn't feel very cheated. The action includes a good number of funny scenes, but I'd say that overall the calmer scenes are the funnier ones. By the end, the film gets too wrapped up in its surprisingly complex plot. I actually didn't know what was going on, and was questioning why a comedy like this contained such a hard to understand story. There are so many traitors and sides that it's hard to who is fighting who and why. While this is going on, the movie contains less laughs than other parts, and I wasn't enjoying it all that much.In the end, the movie gets by nicely thanks to genuine laughs, consistent entertainment value, and a fun cast despite the oddly complex plot and sometimes repetitive jokes. A mostly satisfying comedy that will mostly satisfy audiences.

In 2015, most comedies centered around espionage and spy-action seem overworked at this point. We've seen too many films that revolve around the same plot with A-List actors embarrassing themselves as brainless superspies that try to save the world. With this in mind, I was initially turned off by "Spy" and I honestly had no intention of seeing it, let alone spend the money to catch it in theatres. When the film debuted and it was met with stellar reviews, I changed my mind and gave it a shot. It was a worthwhile decision: Melissa McCarthy breaks away from the loud and obnoxious typecast just enough to present a hero who is strong, badass, and hilarious. Jude Law and Jason Statham back her up with witty humor and solid gags that give this film a refreshing charge. It is also wonderfully directed by Paul Feig, who really nails the action sequences while simultaneously maintaining good humor that doesn't wear out. I know that the success of this film will draw forward many other attempts to join the already dragging bandwagon, but I find it hard to believe that any of them will trump this one.

Spy is everything this year's Hot Pursuit wished it was: a giant, female-centric, laugh-out-loud action comedy that's sprawling in its set-pieces, yet shining in its silliness. Through its physical comedy and unexpectedly cool combat scenes, it still manages to feel like a screwball comedy throwback with stellar verbal sparring between the great actors. So it's not groundbreaking like Mad Max: Fury Road, or mind-boggling like Ex Machina, but those aren't the goals. Spy will simply make you happy, nothing more, nothing less; and sometimes that's really enough.Much of that pure joy comes directly from the cast. From top to bottom, these gals and guys propel Spy to higher levels than movies of its kind often get. Everyone just seems to be having an absolute blast and that fun is contagious. Janney and Byrne stand out as solid and strong comedic presences. Hart and Statham steal every scene they are in, each playing with their own Hollywood identities to great effect. At the center of it all, McCarthy and Feig steer the ship swimmingly, often managing heartbreaking honesty and side-splitting hilarity all at once.This mixture can, at times, make the proceedings feel more "cute" than LOL funny, especially as the movie's somewhat-long runtime feels its length. However, as you settle into the world, you can't help but love the ways in which it takes the self-righteousness out of spy thrillers by highlighting the hilariously mundane minutiae. Will it change your world or even really challenge you intellectually? Not in the least, but it will undoubtedly make you laugh...a lot.

Easily McCarthy's best performance in a while, "Spy" contains at least 10 laugh-out-loud moments and will leave many audience members with the feeling that they should see the movie a second time to catch what they missed while laughing the first time. Best of all, director Feig has crafted a compelling spy movie that happens to be ridiculously hilarious. There in nothing that happens in the spy part of the movie that you haven't already seen 1,000 times before, but the cast is superb, their comedic timing is flawless, and the action sequences are terrific and, in the case of McCarthy's fight scene in the kitchen with a young assassin, top-notch!

Paul Feig, the TV director turned box office freight train thanks to Bridesmaids and Heat, is back with his star Melissa McCarthy. This time the queen of comedy serve up a raucous riff on all things Bond as McCarthy dives into high stakes espionage and hilarity. McCarthy can be hit or miss lately. While Bridesmaids earned her a rare Oscar nomination for a comedic performance and Heat with Sandra Bullock struck gold at the Cineplex, her next outings - Identity Thief and Tammy - were reviled by critics and audiences alike. But back in Feig's hands, she is once again at the top of her game. As Susan Cooper, a bored analyst who watches the back of her dreamboat agent Jude Law, McCarthy pines for romance and adventure. She gets it when Law runs into trouble and her superiors send her in undercover. The laughs are plentiful and not just from McCarthy. Rose Byrne (Bridesmaids; Neighbors) crushes it as the evil arms dealing nemesis, Rayna Boyanov; Jason Statham sends up his tough guy image to great effect (has he ever acted better than this?); and Miranda Hart as McCarthy's eyes and ears is destined for a lot of plum supporting roles. With her English accent and drool timing, she is a blast and gets some of the best lines. It's a hard R-rated funfest with even Allison Janney getting to utter lines like "Thanks for the through intel on Rayna, Susan. But in the future could you refrain from using the phrase 'thunder c**t' in official reports?" Looking forward to Feig's next effort, the all-girl re-launch of Ghostbusters with McCarthy, Kristen Wiig and SNL's Kate McKinnon and Cecily Strong.

The hilarious Spy officially cements Melissa McCarthy's status as true comedy royalty. Spy is her funniest screen effort since Bridesmaids. As CIA agent Susan Cooper, finally getting a chance to wade into the danger zone after years at Langley assisting a handsome spy (a lovably goofy Jude Law), McCarthy nails every laugh, and she does by not being a cheap idiot for laughs. Susan is fully capable of taking down bad guys (including a supremely droll and outrageously funny Rose Byrne as a Bulgarian nuclear arms dealer) and make converts of ultra macho agents like Jason Statham. Susan, who looks like 'someone's homophobic aunt' has long been sold short by her boss (Allison Janney). And McCarthy, who doesn't fit into the typical narrow idea of Hollywood glamour, knows from what she's playing, and she has the last laugh on her critics.In Spy, McCarthy is reunited with the great Paul Feig, who directed her to an Oscar nomination in 2011's Bridesmaids and box-office gold in 2013's The Heat. They make a dynamite combo, with Feig's script bursting with tasty zingers and feminist subtext. As Susan hops all over the globe---Paris, Rome, Budapest--to spy on Al Qaeda-linked terrorist Sergio De Luca (Bobby Cannavale), you get to see her let loose. She's on her own until her office BFF, the excellent Miranda Hart of tv's Call The Midwife, joins up with her to be the Bond girl to her Bond.None of the jokes or the plot should be spoiled, except to say it's filled with hot R-rated action and great raunch. All of it is incredibly entertaining, from Susan's makeovers (going frumpy to fab), to the wickedly fun weapons she has disguised as stool softeners and hemorrhoid patches. And the supporting cast meets her every move. The byplay between McCarthy and Byrne is pure deliciousness. Both have pitch-perfect comic timing. But overall, it's pure pleasure watching McCarthy come out blazing with a hilarious character that cuts to the heart. She's irresistible and unforgettable. As is the movie.

Spy isn't just a funny movie, it's good. Melissa McCarthy leads a powerhouse cast in a comedic take on CIA spies. Every one of these actors worked so well together and with stand-out performances by supporting cast members like Jason Statham, Bobby Cannavale, and the little known Miranda Hart, Spy was over-the-top hilarious. This is easily Paul Feig, and Melissa McCarthy's best pairing, and possibly McCarthy's best movie to date. The movie allowed McCarthy to be two take on two different personalities, which she did well. Make no mistake, I'm not saying she showed "range," just that she was the best of two different characters she does in most movies. Honestly, if Spy could have been a touch shorter, I think it would have packed that much more punch, but that's the most I can criticize it. It's not often I see a movie and don't want to wait for it to come out on DVD to watch again. If you're a fan of McCarthy, a fan of comedies, this is a must see.

Paul Feig and Melissa McCarthy bringing their third comedy film together is another awesome combo of laughs and action. Feig's previous films were also surprisingly funny from Bridesmaids and The Heat, which McCarthy was in both of them. Spy is kind of a satire to the James Bond films; it even has a flashy montage of an opening credit sequence. Spy has enough humor and action to make it worth watching. Melissa McCarthy does have some fair comedy movies out there with some hit and misses. When she is teamed with director Paul Feig, they manage to bring enough humor for every scene. Jason Statham, Rose Byrne, Miranda Hart, and Jude Law all managed to have fun as well. Jason Statham also was funny, with his cocky arrogant attitude as one of the top agents Rick Ford. Statham has been stereotyped in most of his movies; this movie does show he would not disappoint doing a comedy movie. Spy is a good action comedy film that is vulgar, entertaining and has a great cast together.
